results.title: Sandy Powell’s costume designs
results.brief_description: Costume designer Sandy Powell begins her design process with the script, and then consults with directors on how they envision the characters. Next step is choosing fabrics – one of the most important parts of her process because it inspires the costumes.

constellations_primary.name: Sandy, Swinton, Shakespeare and Derek
constellations_primary.description: Tracing costume designer Sandy Powell's ongoing connections with Tilda Swinton, William Shakespeare and Derek Jarman.

results.description:
Costume designer Sandy Powell begins her design process with the script. Once she knows the story, she consults with directors on how they envision the characters. Then she fills books – divided into chapters on each character – with research images before she sources fabric. Choosing the kinds of fabric she will use is one of the most important parts of Powell’s process – the fabric gives her the idea for her costumes.    

In The Favourite (2018), Powell uses historically accurate silhouettes but modern materials like second-hand denim, fake leather and vinyl. While you might think costume designers always sketch their designs first, many don’t, including Powell, who dives straight into creating the costumes. She only makes the sketches after she knows what the costumes look like and the actors have tested them.
description_for_label:
Costume designer Sandy Powell begins her design process with the script. Once she knows the story, she consults with directors on how they envision the characters. Then she fills books – divided into chapters on each character – with research images before she sources fabric. Choosing the kinds of fabric she will use is one of the most important parts of Powell’s process – the fabric gives her the idea for her costumes.    

In The Favourite (2018), Powell uses historically accurate silhouettes but modern materials like second-hand denim, fake leather and vinyl. While you might think costume designers always sketch their designs first, many don’t, including Powell, who dives straight into creating the costumes. She only makes the sketches after she knows what the costumes look like and the actors have tested them.

results.title: Set design in Little J and Big Cuz
results.creator_credit: Tony Thorne and Ned Lander Media Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Five-year-old Little J and nine-year-old Big Cuz are a couple of indigenous Australian kids living with their Nanna and old dog. All their friends are nearby, and school is just a stroll away along a bush track.

constellations_primary.name: Drawing on influences
constellations_primary.description: Waves of animators have been inspired by the style of previous animators to help tell their own stories.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Thorne and Ned Lander Media Pty Ltd
results.description:
There’s a world of adventure over Little J and Big Cuz’s back fence. Their house is magically located at the doorstep of the desert, bush and coast – environments that represent where the show’s writers are from. And as locations in the first animated show made for Indigenous Australian kids by an Indigenous crew, these environments aren’t just settings for great stories – they reflect the different landscapes of the people the show was made for. To the show’s fans, Little J and Big Cuz live in the same place they do.

They also speak like them. Each season, Indigenous communities could choose an episode to have translated into their traditional language. Naturally, they typically picked episodes set in locations that represent their country.
description_for_label:
There’s a world of adventure over Little J and Big Cuz’s back fence. Their house is magically located at the doorstep of the desert, bush and coast – environments that represent where the show’s writers are from. And as locations in the first animated show made for Indigenous Australian kids by an Indigenous crew, these environments aren’t just settings for great stories – they reflect the different landscapes of the people the show was made for. To the show’s fans, Little J and Big Cuz live in the same place they do.

They also speak like them. Each season, Indigenous communities could choose an episode to have translated into their traditional language. Naturally, they typically picked episodes set in locations that represent their country.
